bestBHT.bht: The Pharisees, with their evil motives, came to Jesus not to be instructed but to ensnare him. Their purpose was to tempt him by engaging in a discussion about divorce, possibly in order to accuse him or to see if he would be stricter than Moses had taught. They were well aware that Jesus had already spoken on this subject in Galilee. However, Jesus responded firmly and unwaveringly to their attempts to entangle him and expose him as an inconsistent preacher.

Philip Schaff: Mark 10:2. Mark omits ‘for every cause’ (Matthew), but the whole subject is brought into discussion, a dangerous topic in the territory of Herod, the husband of Herodias.
Archibald T. Robertson: The word means either (see on Matthew 4:1), but their motive was evil.
They may have some such hopes about Jesus, or their purpose may have been to see if Jesus will be stricter than Moses taught.
They knew that he had already spoken in Galilee on the subject (Matthew 5:31).
John Gill: Pharisees came unto him... not to be instructed by him, but to ensnare him.
A divorce might be lawfully made for a cause, or reason, namely, adultery, but not for any, or every cause.
Trying to entangle him by opposing the authority of Moses, should he deny the lawfulness of divorces, or by objecting his former doctrine... and so expose him as an inconsistent preacher.

bhtAttempts.bht: The Pharisees came to Jesus not to be instructed, but to ensnare him. They sought to tempt him by discussing the topic of divorce, a dangerous subject in the territory of Herod, the husband of Herodias. Perhaps they had hopes of finding a way to accuse Jesus or to see if he would be stricter than Moses had taught. They were aware that Jesus had already spoken on this subject before in Galilee. It is clear that their motive was evil, as they sought to entangle him and expose him as an inconsistent preacher. However, they were met with a firm and unwavering response from Jesus.

The Pharisees came to Jesus not to be instructed, but to ensnare him. They sought to tempt him by discussing divorce, perhaps hoping to accuse him or to see if he would be stricter than Moses had taught. Aware that Jesus had already spoken on this subject in Galilee, they tried to entangle him and expose him as an inconsistent preacher. However, Jesus responded firmly and unwaveringly to their evil motives.

The Pharisees, with their evil motives, came to Jesus not to be instructed but to ensnare him. Their purpose was to tempt him by engaging in a discussion about divorce, possibly in order to accuse him or to see if he would be stricter than Moses had taught. They were well aware that Jesus had already spoken on this subject in Galilee. However, Jesus responded firmly and unwaveringly to their attempts to entangle him and expose him as an inconsistent preacher.

The Pharisees came to Jesus with evil motives, seeking to ensnare him by discussing divorce. They may have wanted to accuse him or test if he would be stricter than Moses taught. Aware of his previous teachings on this subject, they hoped to expose him as an inconsistent preacher. However, Jesus responded firmly to their attempts, not allowing himself to be trapped by their devious intentions.

The Pharisees came to Jesus with evil motives, seeking to ensnare him by discussing divorce. They may have wanted to accuse him or test if he would be stricter than Moses taught. Aware of his previous teachings on this subject, they aimed to expose him as an inconsistent preacher. However, Jesus responded firmly, not allowing himself to be trapped by their devious intentions.
